metadata.title: Quantitative Evaluation of Multiple Production of Neutrons Induced by Cosmic Rays in Materials

abstract.text: Neutron measurements for eonfirming d-d cold fusion in condensed matter have been carried out by a number of groups on the basis of a common recognition that the most definitive evidence is to detect neutron. Various attempts to dcpress the noise production and to reduce the background neutron have been performed for a varicty of neutron detectors. Conscquently, it has also bcen a common recognition that low level neutron, which is comparable to the background neu-trom, measurements with low noise, high scnsitivity and stability are extremely diff-cultt'. On the other hand, it is known that neutrons are produced by the nucleon-compe-neat of cosmic rays in their interactions with mattert-t), These phenomena have been neglected on the neutron measurements in nuciear physics, nuclenr technology. health physics etc., because the neutron production rates are very low at the sen level. However, it might be required to take into account the production of neutrons induced by cosmic rays on the low level neutron measurements in cold fusion rescarch. Little is iknown about the quantitative and systematic data to evaluate the neutron production rates in various materials.

body_text.text: In the present work, the production behavior and rates of neutrons induced by cosmic rays in a material have then been studied quantitatively at the sca level (Tokai-mura), magnetic latitude 36.3* morth

In order to reduce the ex-termal background neutron the detector assembly is surrounded by a 0.5 mm thick Cd plate and by a 200 mm layer of 04M boric acid solution (not showm in Fig. 1. All output pulses of the counters are amplified and added for pulne height analysis (PHA. muitichannel scaling (MCS) and pulse interval analysis (PLA). The normal operation of the counters and the noise production are monitored by PHA. The gross and coincidence neutron counting rates are determined by MCS analysis and by the multichannel time spectra obtained by using PIA, respectively, where the coincidence neu-troms are defined as neutron pairs with the pulse interval (0, 500 es). The gross neutron detection eliciency e was 209% on the average in the center hole (150$x400 mm. which was determined by using calibrated mCf and tM'AmOs sources. The gross and coincidence counting rates of the external background neutron are (3.79+0.10)x10-' and (6.7610.20) ×10-'s-, respectively.

The coincidence counting rate for H.O as the material agreed with the plots as shown in Fig. 3, while $c$ for H,O was below the detection limit. On the other hand. $c$ and $c$ for D.O were not consistent with the plots in Fig. 3 and were 6.1 and 3.3 times, respectively, as much as those calculated by the abowe relationships. The multiple production of neutrons duced by cosmic rays are obscrved in the materias in wide range of the periodic table, although the production rates are low and about 10-～10-* n.kg"'.s"'. The neutron production rates per mole of the materials arc propartional to A:-

where A is mean atomic weight of the material. However, the neutron prodsction in D,O is exceptionally higher than that expected from the above relationship. The multiple production of neutrons should be taken into account to evaluate the background ncutron on the low level neutron measurements, especially in cold fusion research.
